message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and CSF analysis suggest Acute flaccid myelitis (AFM). The virus destroys the anterior horn of the spinal cord which contains the cell bodies of lower motor neurons that innervate skeletal muscle. Therefore, the correct answer is (D).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and CSF analysis suggest poliomyelitis, which affects motor neurons in the anterior horn of the spinal cord. The virus destroys the cells that control muscle movements, resulting in the muscle weakness and paralysis seen in the patient.

We refer to the information provided in the question stem. The patient presents with muscle weakness and flaccid paralysis of the lower limbs. A CSF analysis reveals no signs of inflammation, indicating a non-inflammatory process affecting the motor neurons. A throat swab reveals an RNA virus, which likely caused the disease. Among the options, only the destruction of the anterior horn of the spinal cord, where the cell bodies of motor neurons that innervate skeletal muscle are located, would result in flaccid paralysis of muscles. Choice (A) refers to the sensory neurons in the posterior horn, which are not affected in this case. Choice (B) refers to demyelination, which is not a feature of this particular disease. Choice (C) is not a feature of this disease either.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the boy has poliomyelitis, which attacks the anterior horn of the spinal cord. The virus destroys motor neurons, leading to paralysis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of flaccid paralysis and CSF analysis suggest the patient has polio, an RNA virus that destroys motor neurons in the anterior horn of the spinal cord. Option A, posterior horn cells, is not affected by polio, while options B and C are not consistent with the symptoms presented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient has poliomyelitis, which is caused by a virus that targets the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord. Option A and B are not affected by poliovirus. Option C is affected by other viruses such as Coxsackie virus but not poliovirus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of muscle weakness and flaccid paralysis along with the CSF analysis suggest that the virus has infected the anterior horn of the spinal cord. Choice A is incorrect because posterior horn cells are sensory neurons and are not associated with paralysis. Choice B is incorrect because myelin sheaths are not affected by RNA viruses. Choice C is incorrect because muscle cells are not affected by viral infections of the nervous system.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, CSF analysis, and throat swab suggest poliomyelitis, a viral infection that attacks the anterior horn of the spinal cord. Option A is incorrect as posterior horn cells are not involved in polio. Option B is incorrect as myelin sheaths are not damaged in polio. Option C is incorrect as polio does not directly attack or destroy muscle cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and CSF analysis suggest the patient has poliomyelitis, which destroys the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord. The other options are not typically affected by the poliovirus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and CSF analysis suggest poliomyelitis, a viral infection that primarily affects the anterior horn of the spinal cord. None of the other options are affected by this virus.
